headline: John Bolton rejects Trump's claim he doesn't know what burner phones are and insists he discussed them 'several' times after seven-hour gap in January 6 White House call logs was revealed
author: Janon Fisher For Dailymail.Com
sentences:
+6
View gallery
Bolton, who penned a tell-all about his time in the White House, says he and Trump discussed 'burner phones' before
+6
View gallery
The January 6 Capitol riot was aimed at blocking Congress from certifying the election win for Joe Biden and resulted in five deaths and the second impeachment of Trump
+6
View gallery
Former national security adviser John Bolton undermined former President Trump's assertion that he's never heard of a 'burner phone'
+6
View gallery
President Donald Trump made several calls on the morning of January 6 and in the evening, but there is a seven and a half hour gap in telephone activity that day, during which the siege on the Capitol took place
Eleven pages of records leaked to the paper indicate that the former president spoke with his adviser Steve Bannon, Rudy Giuliani, former vice president Mike Pence, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, Congressman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), Fox News commentator Sean Hannity and others.

White House call logs obtained by The Washington Post show a more than seven-hour gap in Trump's phone use - from 11:17 a.m. to 6:54 p.m. - on the day the Capitol was stormed, suggesting that he either didn't communicate with anyone by phone as the chaos unfolded or he used a different phone.

The Washington Post identified two calls placed during the riot, one to Congressman Mike Lee (Utah-R) and another to House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (California-R), that do not appear on the call logs, but have been documented elsewhere, suggesting he used another phone.

Former Donald Trump national security advisor John Bolton refuted the ex-president's claim that he doesn't know what a 'burner phone' is, saying the two had 'several discussions' in the past about 'how people have used burner phones to avoid having their calls scrutinized.'

But Bolton, who had a falling out with Trump after the foreign affairs diplomat was called to testify for the second impeachment trial, told the Post that the two had 'several discussions' about burner phones.

The House panel probing the January 6 Capitol attack voted Tuesday evening to hold Steve Bannon (pictured) in contempt for refusing to testify
None of the men spoke to the Washington Post about their calls.
The House select committee investigating the insurrection is looking into whether or not Trump used a 'burner phone' to talk to advisers and Republican lawmakers that day.

+6
View gallery
The nine-member panel includes two anti-Trump Republicans â€“ Representatives Liz Cheney of Wyoming (left) and Adam Kinzinger of Illinois (right)
He made several other calls to Republican advisors and White House staff and capped the night with a call to the presidential personnel director John McEntee.
Trump attend the infamous rally that proceeded the charge on the Capitol Building and was back at the White House by 1:21 p.m.
The former Commander-in-Chief denied that he used a disposable phone, claiming he doesn't know what a 'burner phone' is.
'I have no idea what a burner phone is, to the best of my knowledge I have never even heard the term,' he told the Post.
Trump's phone activity picks back up again shortly before 7 p.m. when he calls White House aide Daniel Scavino Jr.
The last call that he placed in the morning at 11:17 was not identified in the call logs.
He also spoke to White House counsel Pat Cipollone and Kayleigh McEnany moments later.
He recorded a video for social media at 4:03 trying to quell the unrest.
